content: What Japanese art form's name translates to "pictures of the floating world" and was prominent from the 17th to 19th centuries?

Ah, I think I know this one. It's Ukiyo-e, right? Yeah, Ukiyo-e is the Japanese art form that translates to "pictures of the floating world." It was really popular during the Edo period, which was from the 17th to the 19th centuries. It mostly features woodblock prints and paintings of various subjects like landscapes, portraits of famous people, kabuki actors, and scenes from everyday life. It's known for its unique style and has influenced many artists around the world, including the Impressionists in Europe.
